content.text: (i) shape \(A\) onto shape \(B\)
(ii) shape \(A\) onto shape \(C\).
(a) Describe fully the single transformation that maps
(i) shape \(A\) after a reflection in the line \(y=2\)
(ii) shape \(A\) after an enlargement, scale factor \(-2\), centre \((0,0)\).
(b) On the grid, draw the image of
Find the value of \(s\) when \(a=9.8\) and \(t=20\).
(b) Solve.
(c) Expand and simplify.
(d) Rearrange \(A=2 b^{2}-3 c^{3}\) to make \(c\) the subject.
(i) The average distance of Mars from the Sun is \(2.279 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~km}\).
Write this distance as an ordinary number.
(ii) The planet Uranus has a diameter that is \(35.8 \%\) of the diameter of Jupiter.
Calculate the diameter of Uranus.
(iii) The ratio diameter of Neptune : diameter of Saturn can be written in the form \(1:n\).
Find the value of \(n\).
(iv) Find the average distance of Neptune from the Sun as a percentage of the average distance of the Earth from the Sun.
(v) Distances within the solar system are also measured in astronomical units (AU). The average distance of Jupiter from the Sun is 5.20 AU .
Calculate the average distance of Mars from the Sun in astronomical units.
(vi) The diameter of Mars is \(39.2 \%\) greater than the diameter of Mercury.
Calculate the diameter of Mercury.
3 (a) The table shows information about some of the planets in the solar system.
(i) Show that one light year is \(9.461 \times 10^{12} \mathrm{~km}\), correct to 4 significant figures.
(ii) The distance from the Andromeda Galaxy to Earth is \(2.40 \times 10^{19} \mathrm{~km}\).
Calculate the time taken for light to travel from this galaxy to Earth. Give your answer in millions of years.
(b) One light year is the distance that light travels in a year of 365.25 days.
The speed of light is \(2.9979 \times 10^{5}\) kilometres per second.
(i) Complete the tree diagram.
(ii) Find the probability that
4 (a) Lucia has two fair spinners.
Spinner \(A\) is five-sided and is numbered \(1,2,3,4,5\).
Spinner \(B\) is nine-sided and is numbered \(3,3,4,4,4,5,5\).
Lucia spins the two spinners and records whether they land on a prime number.
(b) the two numbers are not both prime.
(c) Lucia spins Spinner \(B\) twice.
Find the probability that the two numbers it lands on add up to 9 or more.
(d) Lucia keeps spinning Spinner \(B\) until it lands on a 4 .
Find an expression, in terms of \(n\), for the probability that this happens on the \(n\) th spin.
\(A C D\) is a right-angled triangle.
\(B\) is on \(A C\) and \(B C=54.5 \mathrm{~m}\).
\(A D=83.2 \mathrm{~m}\) and angle \(A B D=38^{\circ}\).
Calculate angle \(A C D\).

\(E F G\) is a right-angled triangle.
A circle can be drawn that passes through the three vertices of the triangle.
On the diagram, mark the position of the centre of the circle with a cross.
Explain how you decide.
In triangle \(L M N\), the ratio \(\angle \mathrm{angle} L:\angle \mathrm{angle} M:\angle \mathrm{angle} N=4:5:6\).
In triangle \(P Q R, P Q=6 \mathrm{~cm}, P R=4 \mathrm{~cm}\) and \(Q R=5 \mathrm{~cm}\).
Calculate the difference between the largest angle in triangle \(P Q R\) and the largest angle in triangle \(L M N\).

Find the 50th term of this sequence.

content.text: (i) Show that the volume of the solid is \(692 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\), correct to the nearest cubic centimetre.
[The volume, \(V\), of a sphere with radius \(r\) is \(V=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}\).]
(ii) A mathematically similar solid is made of silver. In this solid, the cylinder has radius 0.6 cm . \(1 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of silver has a mass of 10.49 grams.
Calculate the total mass of this silver solid.
The diagram shows a solid formed by joining two hemispheres and a cylinder.
The radius of the large hemisphere is 5.4 cm .
The radius of the small hemisphere and the radius of the cylinder are both 3.6 cm .
The height of the cylinder is 6.5 cm .
(i) Calculate the length of the arc of this sector.
Give your answer as a multiple of \(\pi\).
(ii) A cone is made from this sector by joining \(O A\) to \(O B\).
Calculate the volume of the cone.
[The volume, \(V\), of a cone with radius \(r\) and height \(h\) is \(V=\frac{1}{3} \pi r^{2} h\).]
\(A O B\) is a sector of a circle, centre \(O\). \(A O=10 \mathrm{~cm}\) and the sector angle is \(216^{\circ}\).
(iii) \(\mathrm{gh}(2)\).
(a) Find
Find the value of \(x\).
(c) Simplify \(\mathrm{g}\left(x^{\frac{1}{4}}\right)+\mathrm{gg}(x)+1\).
This can be written in the form \(\mathrm{f}(x)=a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d\).
Find the value of each of \(a, b, c\) and \(d\).
(i) Find the coordinates of \(C\).
(ii) Find \(\overrightarrow{B A}\).
(iii) Find \(|\overrightarrow{C A}|\).
10 (a) \(A B C\) is a triangle.
\(B\) is the point \((1,-10, A)\) is the point \((4,14)\) and \(\overrightarrow{C A}=\left(\begin{array}{r}-11 \\ 8\end{array}\right)\).
(i) Show that \(\overrightarrow{O R}=\frac{2}{5} \mathbf{a}+\frac{3}{5} \mathbf{b}\).
\(O M N\) is a triangle.
\(\overrightarrow{O M}=\mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{O N}=\mathbf{b}\).
\(R\) is a point on \(M N\) such that \(M R:R N=3:2\).
\(O R T\) is a straight line.
11 (a) Differentiate \(x^{3}-4 x^{2}-3 x\).
(b) A curve has equation \(y=x^{3}-4 x^{2}-3 x\).
Work out the coordinates of the two stationary points. Show all your working.
(c) Determine whether each stationary point is a maximum or a minimum. Show all your working.
